content.question: The Taylor series for a function f about x = 0 is given by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <munderover> <mo>∑</mo> <mrow> <mi>n</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> <mi>∞</mi> </munderover> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <msup> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>n</mi> <mo>+</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> </msup> </mrow> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> <mi>n</mi> <mo>+</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>!</mo> </mrow> </mfrac> <mtext> </mtext> <msup> <mi>x</mi> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> <mi>n</mi> </mrow> </msup> </mrow> </mstyle> <mtext> </mtext> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4EED@</annotation> </semantics> </math> and converges to f for all real numbers x. If the fourth-degree Taylor polynomial for f about x = 0 is used to approximate <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mfrac> <mn>1</mn> <mn>2</mn> </mfrac> </mrow> <mo>)</mo></mrow> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3A6C@</annotation> </semantics> </math> alternating series error bound?
